lines.text: How's the arm, Charlie?
All right, boss. It's my drinking arm, not my loving arm.
It beats me how women can go for you cowboys.
Oh, yeah. Women like the smell of a horse on a man. That makes them giggle.
Well, the smell of a horse on me never did me no good. Just makes them get up and move away.
Maybe you're associating with the wrong horses.
sounds just as bad no matter who sings it.
I wouldn't go in there for a bottle of whiskey and a redhead to pour it.
I've been dreaming every night about them Mexican gals for the last week. I wouldn't take $400 for what I dreamed last night.
You've been talking in your sleep, too. I wish you would think of something else to dream about for a change.
I'll tell you what you do. You think of something better to dream about... I'll dream about it.

Anybody know the right words? Uh, something like this happens, people start asking how come it happened. I mean uh... was it his fault... was... was somebody else's fault? Well, that isn't for us to say. You see, we don't know all the answers. All we know is a man is dead and that's that. In the long run, I don't think it would have made any difference anyhow. I mean, if it hadn't been a snake that had got him, it would have been a steer, or a Comanche... his horse might have stumbled into a prairie dog hole some dark night. He was a good man with cattle and always did the best he knew how. I hope somebody can say the same over me.

[after a snake is thrown on him]
He got me.

[after shooting a hole in a pipe]
I thought I saw a spider.
I thought I was gonna ride with some men. You're just a bunch of animals.
I know Señor Harris, he writes poetry.
He does?
I used to.
We rounded up most of the herd... that is, all we could find.
How many head did we lose?
Just over 200.
That's a lot of cows.
Yeah, it is. It's too bad. It's too bad for you.
What?
We found all my cows. It seems it was yours that ran off and got lost.
Well, what makes you think you'd like to go trail herding?
Well, ah, all my life I've been dreaming about going into the cattle business. Getting out on the trail and... and I hate Chicago. I'd like to live in the open. You know what I mean?

Oh, yeah, I know what you mean. You mean lying out there under the stars listening to the boys singing around the campfire. And your faithful old horse standing there grazing at the grass by your side. You do much riding?
Me? Well, I bet I could ride all day and all night.
Oh, is that a fact? You know, I bet you like horses.
Yes, sir, I sure do.

Yeah, I thought so. Well, you're an idiot! You're a dreaming idiot, and that's the worst kind. You know what the trail is really like? Dust storms all day, cloudbursts all night. A man has got to be a fool to want that kind of life.
Tell the boys the time you ate them Indians, huh? Come on!
Ah, I only ate but one injun in my whole life. An even then it was just a haunch.
[a little later]
Hey, old Joe would be rather fighting Indians all the time, wouldn't you, Joe? Look at him, boss. It makes him hungry just thinking about it.
Ah, cut it out, will you, Curtis? I was near starving to death. In fact, I didn't even know that injun. Anyway, I threw away everything except for one haunch.
Which haunch did you keep, Joe?
Well, the left one, of course! The right one is the working haunch. They're always tough.
What about this fellow Reece?
He's all right if you're all right.
When does he pay off? At the end of the run?
You ask him for what's coming in the middle a river crossing, and he'll pay you off. He'll pay you off in dry bills.

And all that hogwash about horses! The loyalty of the horse! The intelligence of the horse! The intelligence? You know a horse has a brain just about the size of a walnut. They're mean, they're treacherous and they're stupid. There isn't a horse born that had enough sense to move away from a hot fire. No sensible man loves a horse. He tolerates the filthy animal only because riding is better than walking.
You're getting old, Doc.
No, it ain't that. A man has to have something besides a gun and a saddle. You just can't make it all by yourself.
If you had anything inside you worth saving, I'd beat you until you couldn't stand up. But it wouldn't do any good because you'll never learn. You haven't gotten tougher... you've gotten miserable!
How did you determine which cows were yours and which were mine?
It was easy. I used a crowbar.
